channel.title: Stories from theatlantic.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best theatlantic.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: We Are Living In A Failed State
item.description: The coronavirus didn't break America. It revealed what was already broken.

item.title: The Coronavirus Revealed America's Failures
item.description: The coronavirus didn't break America. It revealed what was already broken.

item.title: New Zealand's Prime Minister May Be The Most Effective Leader On The Planet
item.description: Jacinda Ardern's leadership style, focused on empathy, isn't just resonating with her people; it's putting the country on track for success against the coronavirus.

item.title: Colorado: Images of the Centennial State
item.description: A few glimpses of Colorado's landscape and some of the animals and people calling it home.
item.kicker: HIGH PLAINS TO THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS

item.title: The Quiet Revolution Of Animal Crossing
item.description: In the midst of a pandemic, it's delightful to imagine doing whatever you like without worrying about making a living.

item.title: How Facebook Works For Trump
item.description: Donald Trump won the presidency by using the social network's advertising machinery in exactly the way the company wanted. He's poised to do it again.

item.title: How You'll Grocery Shop After The Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The coronavirus will change grocery stores, and probably not for the better.

item.title: Few Statistics Tell You Anything About COVID-19. Here's One That Does
item.description: The proportion of coronavirus tests with positive results could be a window into just how bad the U.S. outbreak is.

item.title: The Great Immunity Divide
item.description: When yellow fever swept through 19th-century New Orleans, immunity became so valuable, it was worth risking death for.

item.title: A $2 Billion Settlement — And The Lawyer Whose Clients Didn't Exist
item.description: A well-known attorney helped land a $2 billion settlement for Gulf Coast seafood-industry workers after the BP oil spill. But who was he really representing?

item.title: After Social Distancing, A Strange Purgatory Awaits
item.description: Life right now feels very odd. And it will feel odd for months — and even years — to come.

item.title: Vermont's Great Experiment
item.description: A few weeks ago, National Guardsmen in the state got an impossible assignment — construct a hospital four days. And then they pulled it off.

item.title: What Do You Miss Most About Touch?
item.description: Amid a pandemic that is profoundly decreasing skin-on-skin contact, the author asked people to share their most affecting tactile experiences.

item.title: How Coronavirus Will Create A New Working Class
item.description: Experts predict the outbreak will lead to a rise in populism. But will workers turn their rage toward corporate CEOs, or middle-class "elites"?

item.title: What Nurses Want You To Know
item.description: Preexisting staffing shortages and dismal pay are colliding with a crisis that's testing the limits of the people caring for the sick and elderly.

item.title: 'There Is No Going Back' — What Does Our Pandemic Summer Hold?
item.description: The fight against the coronavirus won't be over when the US reopens. Here's how the nation must prepare itself.

item.title: The Anxious Child And The Crisis Of Modern Parenting
item.description: How to raise a resilient child in 2020
item.kicker: THE KIDS MAY OR MAY NOT BE ALRIGHT

item.title: The Woman Who Is Remaking AMC
item.description: "The least safe thing to do is something safe," says Sarah Barnett, the unconventional TV executive behind "Killing Eve," which is back for a third season.

item.title: We're Not Ready For This Kind Of Grief
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic will leave lasting emotional scars.

item.title: Easter Services In A Distanced World
item.description: Images from around the world showing what Easter Sunday services look like during a global pandemic.
item.kicker: PROBABLY SHOULDN'T HAVE RISEN QUITE YET

item.title: Trump's New Auto Rollback Is An Economic Disaster
item.description: According to the administration's own math, the pollution rules could eliminate jobs, discourage driving, and inflict billions in damage.

item.title: Generation C Has Nowhere To Turn
item.description: Recent history suggests young people could see their careers derailed, finances shattered, and social lives upended.

item.title: Dunkin', Classic Rock And The Open Road: An Ode To Driving In America
item.description: A Brit learns to love roadtripping in the USA.

item.title: After The Pandemic, The Office Dress Code Should Never Come Back
item.description: Are "fancy" sweatpants here for good?

item.title: Millennials Are The New Lost Generation
item.description: They're facing a second once-in-a-lifetime downturn at a critical moment.

item.title: The City That Has Flattened The Coronavirus Curve
item.description: Mayor London Breed's early and aggressive moves to contain the outbreak have made San Francisco a national model in fighting the pandemic.

item.title: Unexpected Movie Masterpieces To Watch In Quarantine
item.description: Some were blasted by critics, some flopped at the box office and all are ripe to attain cult-classic status.

item.title: Why We're Running Out Of Masks
item.description: The United States' secretive medical stockpile was prepped for a bombing, not a pandemic.

item.title: The Coronavirus Pandemic Will Cleave America In Two
item.description: In the coming months and years, there will really be two pandemics in America.

item.title: The Two States Where Trump's COVID-19 Response Could Backfire In 2020
item.description: Voters in Michigan and Florida may be more likely than others to blame or credit him for how the outbreak unfolds.

item.title: The Three Equations For A Happy Life
item.description: How to increase happiness, according to research.
item.kicker: DOING MATH, FOR A GOOD REASON

item.title: The Best Hopes For A Coronavirus Drug
item.description: If there is a way to stop COVID-19, it will be by blocking its proteins from hijacking, suppressing, and evading humans' cellular machinery.

item.title: The Best Hopes For A Coronavirus Drug
item.description: If there is a way to stop COVID-19, it will be by blocking its proteins from hijacking, suppressing and evading humans' cellular machinery.

item.title: What Happens When A Joke Is Followed By Silence
item.description: Usually, that's bad. The pandemic makes it normal.

item.title: The People Who Profited Off The Trail Of Tears
item.description: The deportation of Native Americans westward in the 1830s was fueled by busy bankers and unchecked avarice.

item.title: The Most-Watched Show In America Is A Moral Failure
item.description: Netflix's "Tiger King" is the apotheosis of extreme storytelling: the more unfathomable and ethically dubious, the better.

item.title: Closing The Parks Is Ineffective Pandemic Theater
item.description: Public green spaces are good for the immune system and the mind — and they can be rationed to allow for social distancing.

item.title: The Supreme Court's Wisconsin Decision Is A Terrible Sign For November
item.description: The justices are forcing citizens to choose between voting and staying safe from the coronavirus. This fall's election could be no different.

item.title: 'Contact Tracing' Could Free America From Quarantine
item.description: How does it work? And will it infringe on privacy rights?

item.title: The Secret Cruelty Of T.S. Eliot
item.description: Before she died, Emily Hale donated love letters she had received from the author while his wife was ill. Now public, the writings reveal his quiet duplicity.

item.title: What The Racial Data Shows About Coronavirus
item.description: The pandemic seems to be hitting people of color the hardest.

item.title: A Pandemic Is Upon Us. Time To Shoot Your Shot?
item.description: Crushes, like most everything else, get more urgent when the world is engulfed in chaos.

item.title: How To Actually Use The Defense Production Act
item.description: There is no magic in the DPA's mere invocation. The question is what that invocation makes possible and whether it serves the country's complex supply needs.

item.title: The 9/11 Era Is Over
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic and a chapter of history that should have expired long ago.

item.title: This Is What Happens When The Federal Government Abandons You
item.description: Local officials and health-care workers are losing faith in the national response and struggling to improvise their own solutions.

item.title: How Bill de Blasio Failed New York City
item.description: Leadership is never more apparent than when it is missing.

item.title: A Long Pandemic Could Stretch The International Order To Its Breaking Point
item.description: The greatest error that geopolitical analysts can make may be believing that the crisis will be over in three to four months.

item.title: The Enemy The Military Isn't Prepared To Fight
item.description: Even as it's called upon to aid the coronavirus response across the country, the military is struggling to contain the disease among its own personnel.

item.title: Canceling Everything Was The Easy Part. The Decisions Are Only Going To Get Harder
item.description: Shutting entire states down was painful, but clearly necessary. Governors still have many ugly choices ahead of them.

item.title: The Economy Is Ruined. It Didn't Have To Be This Way
item.description: Almost 10 million Americans have already filed for unemployment benefits. Congress can still act to stem the tide.
